newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Japan troubles show need for strong government - Lee.
newsitem.headline: Japan troubles show need for strong government - Lee.

text.p: Singapore patriarch Lee Kuan Yew said Japan's economic problems in recent years reflect lack of a strong government, the Straits Times reported on Monday.

The newspaper quoted Lee, Singapore's Senior Minister, as saying in an off-the-cuff speech on Sunday that Japan's economy faltered after the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) lost decisive control of parliament.
"For 37, 38 years, the LDP had a decisive majority and governed Japan in a decisive way. They could take hard measures, tough policies and decisions, and carry the economy forward," Lee said.
But he said Japan now lacked political stability and "they cannot take decisive measures to get the people to accept hard decisions and to get the economy going again".

The LDP ruled Japan for 38 years until an election in 1993. While it came back into government in mid-1994, that was as part of a coalition, and in a general election over the weekend it failed to win an outright majority.
Lee was using Japan as an example of why strong and decisive governments, like that of Singapore's People's Action Party (PAP), can help economies improve.

The newspaper quoted him as saying, "Remember: do not complain that you have a strong government in the People's Action Party. You will start knowing what life would be like when you end up with a weak government that cannot act and the economy is in trouble and the country is in trouble."
Singapore is experiencing an economic slowdown at the moment with exports lagging, but Lee said due to good economic management, "we have no unemployment, no hardship, nobody has felt the pinch".
The PAP has controlled Singapore's government since 1959.

Lee also pointed to Thailand, saying the country would enjoy 40 to 50 percent more economic growth if it had a strong government instead of a succession of coalition governments which are "in the nature of things weak and unstable".
